Text:
Plants can grow mold in the soil.
  • Molds are microscopic fungi that live in plant soil and animal matter.
If mold is a problem in the home, clean up the mold and eliminate the source.
  • Maintain low indoor humidity, ideally between 30-50% relative humidity.

  • Humidity levels can be measured by hygrometers, which are available at local hardware stores.

targets.Name: Plant

Text:
Tobacco smoke is unhealthy for everyone, especially people with asthma.
  • Keep a strict smoke-free environment at all times
  • No smoking indoors, in homes, cars, or wherever the person with asthma may spend time, as second-hand smoke can be an asthma trigger.

Third-hand smoke is residual tobacco smoke contamination that remains after the cigarette is extinguished. This residue can linger in the air and on the clothes of the person, and on surfaces of the area the smoker has frequented.
  • Always smoke outside far away from the home, car, etc.

  • Use cover up clothing, pull back hair, and wear a hat while smoking outdoors. Leave smoke-contaminated clothing outside of the home. Change clothes, wash hands and face, and rinse mouth after smoking.

targets.Name: Man

Text:
Pay attention to pollen levels.
  • Keep windows closed in the child's bedroom.

  • Use window filters, air conditioning, and air purifiers to filter out pollen airborne in the home.
This is a window. It is not an asthma trigger.
targets.Name: Window

Text:
Furry pets can trigger an asthma attack.
  • Keep furry pets out of bedrooms.

  • Wash furry pets often.

Furry pets can trigger an asthma attack.

  • Keep furry pets out of bedrooms.

  • Wash furry pets often.

Type this in for dog
targets.Name: Dog

Text:
Dust mites live in items made of thick fibers, such as upholstered furniture.
  • Keep humidity level in home under 50%.

  • Vacuum furniture frequently.

  • When possible, consider replacing with occlusive material such as leather.

Dust mites live in items made of thick fibers, such as upholstered furniture.
  • Keep humidity level in home under 50%.

  • Vacuum furniture frequently.

  • When possible, consider replacing with occlusive material such as leather.
targets.Name: Couch

Text:
Wood fireplaces and wood burning stoves produce wood smoke and air pollution. The smoke can be an inhaled irritant--if you can smell smoke, you are breathing smoke.
  • Avoid using a wood fireplace or wood burning stove indoors. Look into cleaner heating appliances.

  • Only burn clean, dry wood. Other materials can produce smoke and fumes that may be toxic.

  • Consider the use of pellet stoves. According to the EPA, they are the least polluting.

  • Ensure professional cleaning and inspection of fireplace, chimney, and wood burning stoves are done annually or more often to make sure there is no leak of wood smoke into the home.
